Smithy, an extensible API definition language

Smithy is a protocol-agnostic interface definition language and set of tools that builds clients, servers, and documentation for any programming language.
Get started Specifications 
namespace example.weather

service Weather {
  version: "2006-03-01",
  resources: [City],
  operations: [GetCurrentTime]
}

resource City {
  identifiers: { cityId: CityId },
  read: GetCity,
  list: ListCities,
  resources: [Forecast],
}

Protocol-agnostic

Smithy is designed to work with any programming language, describe services running in any environment, and work with any kind of transport or serialization format.

Extensible

Smithy models can be extended through traits. There are many built-in traits to affect things like behavior and serialization, and custom traits can be added for additional functionality.

Enforce standards & consistency

Customizable standards and validation constraints ensure that APIs adhere to any kind of standard or convention. Rule sets can be shared and applied to all APIs in an organization.

Resource based

Smithy is defined in terms of resources and operations you can enact on them. Explicitly defining resources provides rich metadata about an API that can be used to build higher-level client tooling and derive artifacts from a model.

Why did you develop Smithy?

With thousands of operations across hundreds of public web services, AWS needed a simple way to describe APIs that could adapt to change and support a wide range of services. At AWS, we provide our customers with extensive documentation, strongly typed client libraries, high-level abstractions like paginators, and tooling in many different programming languages. Existing interface definition languages available outside of AWS were either not compatible with our existing services, not extensible enough to meet our needs, or not strict enough to provide the right customer experience.

Smithy isn't really new. The Smithy IDL is an evolution of an interface definition language that was developed internally at Amazon. Smithy models are compatible with the tens-of-thousands of web services used internally within Amazon and the hundreds of web services provided by AWS.

Smithy is built for code generation and tools. Smithy models were designed for the purpose of generating clients, servers, and documentation in multiple programming languages. To achieve this, Smithy models are completely normalized, which makes models easy to traverse, validate, and diff. Normalization also ensures that every shape has an explicit name to aid in code generation.

Smithy balances extensibility and constraints. Traits are used to extend a model and add capabilities that are not part of the core specification. For example, AWS defines AWS-specific traits that are used to generate other metadata documents that are derived from Smithy models. While extensibility is a key design requirement, Smithy provides a built-in validation system for ensuring that traits are used properly, don't conflict with other traits, are applied only to the correct places in a model, and are configured correctly when used in a model.

Smithy is protocol agnostic. Smithy decouples the transport layer of web services from the data structures and capabilities of the service so that they can evolve independently.

Why is Smithy protocol-agnostic?

  • Most web service customers don't care about the wire-level format of the web services they consume; they care about how they can easily and efficiently integrate their systems with a web service in a way thatâ€™s idiomatic to the language of their choice.
  • Requirements of web services and clients change over time. XML was once the dominant serialization format of the Web, but that distinction has now been passed on to JSON. As web service providers grow and face scaling challenges, they might wish to utilize a more efficient binary protocol rather than using JSON or even HTTP.
  • A protocol-agnostic IDL focuses more on the interfaces and abstractions that are provided to customers rather than bytes over the wire.

What is the difference between Smithy and OpenAPI?

The primary difference between Smithy and OpenAPI is that Smithy is protocol-agnostic. This allows Smithy to describe a broader range of services, metadata, and capabilities.
